issues.description: The solution introduces a `LectureName` class and changes the type of the `lectureName` attribute from `String` (as specified in the UML and described in the problem statement) to `LectureName`. This deviates from the intended design, will confuse students, and prevents a correct implementation matching the specification.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a `String` type for the `lectureName` attribute in the solution’s `Lecture` class instead of introducing a new `LectureName` class to align with the UML and problem description.

issues.description: The solution’s constructor signature takes a `LectureName` parameter for `lectureName` rather than a `String`, conflicting with the problem’s requirement to initialize the `lectureName` attribute as a `String` in the order specified by the UML.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the constructor to accept a `String lectureName` parameter (followed by the other `int` parameters in the specified order) instead of `LectureName lectureName`.

issues.description: The problem statement and UML diagram define the lectureName attribute as a String, but the solution repository introduces a separate LectureName class to represent this concept. This divergence in identifier and type mapping can confuse students who expect lectureName to be a String field as specified in the exercise.
issues.suggested_fix: Remove the LectureName class and change the Lecture.lectureName attribute back to a String type. Ensure getLectureName and setLectureName work directly with String to align with the UML diagram and exercise requirements.
